title: How bad is booze?
intro: Do you enjoy a glass or two of wine? How about three or four? Is beer your favourite drink or do you go for gin? Rob and Alice discuss how good or bad alcohol is for you. They also talk about what risk to your health regular drinking may have.
this_week_question: What is the name of the main process involved in producing alcohol? Is it…
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: the headache and sickness you can feel after drinking too much alcohol
the belief that drinking more alcohol when you already have a hangover will make you feel better

vocab.text: don't knock it until you've tried it
vocab.desc: try something before you criticize it
doubtful about whether something is true or not
the process in which yeast or bacteria change sugar to alcohol

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I'm Rob…

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: You look very pale, Rob. Are you OK?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, I was at a rather boozy wedding party last night. And I had a bit too much champagne. Do you know any good hangover cures?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: A hangover is the headache and sickness you can feel after drinking too much alcohol. And a cure is something that makes you better. Well, I'm teetotal – I don't drink alcohol. So, I'd say the best hangover cure is not to drink in the first place.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: You don't believe in hair of the dog then?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No, Rob, I don't. Hair of the dog is the belief that drinking more alcohol when you already have a hangover will make you feel better! And boozy means lots of alcohol.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I can see I'm not going to get much sympathy from you. So I'm going to take a couple of painkillers and let you tell everyone what the subject of today's show is.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Alright then. Well, it's drinking too much, Rob. And I have a question for you. What is the name of the main process involved in producing alcohol? Is it… a) fermentation? b) hydration? Or c) purification?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, I know it has something to do with water so I'm going to go for b) hydration. It rings a bell from chemistry lessons at school.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out later on in the show whether you were listening carefully in class, Rob.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, er… no comment.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, most people are aware of the links between smoking and cancer, but fewer are aware that drinking alcohol is linked to an increased risk of future health problems. The UK government is currently trying to raise awareness with their new guidelines on how much it's safe to drink. Let's hear what Dr Michael Moseley has to say about health risks.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr Michael Moseley, Science journalist and TV presenter Unfortunately whatever level of alcohol you are drinking it is likely to increase your risk of some forms of cancer, particularly breast cancer, but also other rarer forms of cancer like head, neck, and the throat. The rest are quite low at moderate drinking but they do rise rapidly.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So any drinking at all – even one small glass of wine with your evening meal – raises your risk of cancer? Is that right?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. And the health risk increases with the amount you drink.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But I thought wine was supposed to be good for you?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It's a popular belief, but medical evidence doesn't seem to support this view. Let's listen to Dr Michael Moseley again on this.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr Michael Moseley, Science journalist and TV presenter Now there's long been this idea there is this marvellous stuff in red wine called 'resveratrol' which is said to reduce your risk of all sorts of things. Unfortunately the amount you'd have to consume would be so huge that the downsides of drinking red wine would swiftly overwhelm them.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And the downside of something means the disadvantages. Now Alice, what's your favourite tipple?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, I don't have one Rob because I'm teetotal, remember? A tipple is another way of saying 'an alcoholic drink'. I enjoy beetroot and kale smoothies with a dash of turmeric and ground pepper.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Kale? Yuk, that's disgusting! Now, a smoothie is a thick drink made of fruit or vegetables blended with milk or yogurt or water. Well, I like sweet stuff… maybe a banana smoothie with some honey, but beetroot and kale sounds disgusting!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Don't knock it until you've tried it . And that means to try something before you criticize it.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK, OK, but seriously. A glass of wine makes me happy and relaxed. And there are health studies that suggest being happy is good for your health.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: That's true, but eating and drinking healthily makes me happy! Now moving on, it's important to put the risk of drinking alcohol…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: …or horrible vegetable smoothies…

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: … in context. Statistically, drinking alcohol regularly represents just under 1% lifetime risk of death. But actually an hour of TV watching or eating a bacon sandwich a couple of times a week is more dangerous.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, that's what I like to hear! Though… what if I'm watching TV, enjoying a beer and a lovely bacon sandwich, does that triple my lifetime risk of death?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, Rob, you better ask Professor David Spiegelhalter at the University of Cambridge that question. I was quoting him earlier about the TV watching and the bacon sandwich. He works with statistics, but this is for another programme. Now, let's get on to the serious matter of today's quiz question. I asked: What is the name of the main process involved in producing alcohol? Is it… a) fermentation, b) hydration or c) purification?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, I said b) hydration. Though you were sceptical , weren't you, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. And I was right to be sceptical, which means 'doubtful', because b) is the wrong answer I'm afraid, Rob. The main process involved in producing alcohol is fermentation , which is the process in which yeast or bacteria changes sugar into alcohol. Hydration is the process of making your body absorb water. And purification is the act of removing some harmful things from something. Actually, have this glass of water, Rob. Hydration is a good hangover cure – much better than hair of the dog.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Cheers, Alice!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Now let's hear the words we learned today.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: They are: hangover cure teetotal hair of the dog boozy downside tipple don't knock it until you've tried it sceptical fermentation

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Keep hydrated and don't forget to join us again soon.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
